title: Implement AI incident reporting for federal agencies
organization: Center for Security and Emerging Technology
reasoning: Mandates incident reporting for federal AI, directly advancing IAPS priorities on AI governance, safety, and national security. Specifies agency obligations, timelines, and enforcement. Supported by precedent in cybersecurity and aviation. Politically feasible within federal authority.

title: Establish AI development reporting programs
organization: Center for Security and Emerging Technology
reasoning: Concrete, actionable reporting regime for AI development, closing information gaps between government and developers. Directly aligns with IAPS focus on compute governance and risk monitoring. Realistic, modeled on existing reporting programs.

title: Facilitate cross-government expertise on AI evaluation
organization: Center for Security and Emerging Technology
reasoning: Facilitates cross-government expertise on AI evaluation, leveraging existing agency strengths (NSA, DOE). Highly actionable, addresses real gaps in AI risk evaluation. Strong IAPS alignment with national security and governance.

title: Voluntary AI Incident Reporting Hub
reasoning: Voluntary AI incident reporting hub modeled on successful systems (FAA, FDA). Specific, actionable, and addresses AI risk monitoring. Strong evidence base and feasible under NIST or similar agencies.

title: Create a NIST Foundation to Support AI Mandate
reasoning: Creates a NIST Foundation to support AI mandate, modeled on DOE FESI. Directly supports IAPS-aligned AI governance and safety infrastructure. Bipartisan support and legislative precedent.

title: Clarify policy scope for biological AI models
organization: Center for Security and Emerging Technology
reasoning: Requires policy clarity for chem-bio AI models, addressing a real regulatory gap. Highly specific and actionable, with direct implications for export controls and national security.

title: Ensure Mandatory Shutdown Mechanisms in AI Systems
reasoning: Mandatory shutdown mechanisms for high-risk AI systems (autonomous weapons, infrastructure). Directly advances IAPS safety and national security priorities. Technically feasible, clear implementation path.

reasoning: Deploys AI for critical infrastructure security, instructing DOE/DHS to build anomaly detection tools. Specific, actionable, and directly supports IAPS national security and resilience goals.

reasoning: Standardizes federal AI procurement with clear guidelines, benchmarks, and accountability. Directly addresses a known implementation barrier and aligns with IAPS governance focus.

reasoning: Requires clear documentation and transparency for government AI, especially in high-impact applications. Actionable, measurable, and directly advances IAPS transparency and governance priorities.

title: Training Data Security
reasoning: Training data security standards (NIST-led) with specific controls for poisoning, diversity, and sharing. Concrete, actionable, and addresses a real risk area for AI safety.

reasoning: Establishes real-world AI testing frameworks with NIST leadership, clear criteria, and staged deployment. Highly actionable and aligned with IAPS focus on robust evaluation.
